case_name: Collector of Customs, Bombay v. M/s. Tarachand Gupta Bros.

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 344 of 1967 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 344 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated July 8, 1966 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 17 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 8, 1966 of the, Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 17 of 1964. A. Seyid Muhammad and S. P. Nayar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Respondents suit in respect of fines and penalties recovered from them by the Collector of Customs, Bombay for alleged contravention of S. 3 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 and s. 167(8) of the Sea Customs Act, 1878.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by certificate, arises from the res- pondents suit in respect of fines and penalties recovered from them by the Collector of Customs, Bombay for the alleged companytravention of S. 3 of the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947 and. s. 167 8  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878.

facts.text: Respondents held an import licence dated July 10, 1956 permitting them to import parts and accessories of motor cycles and scooters as per appendix XXVI of the Import Policy Book for July-December 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents held an import licence dated July 10, 1956 permitting them to import parts and accessories of motor cycles and scooters as per appendix XXVI of the Import Policy Book for July-December 1956. Under the said licence, the respondents, imported certain goods which arrived in two companysignments,

facts.text: Respondents imported certain goods which arrived in two consignments, each containing 17 cases, by two different ships.

anchor.surface_text: Under the said licence, the respondents, imported certain goods which arrived in two companysignments, each companytaining 17 cases, by two different ships. According to the respondents, the goods so imported by them were motor cycle parts which their licence authorised them to import.

facts.text: According to respondents, the goods imported were motor cycle parts authorised by their licence.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents, the goods so imported by them were motor cycle parts which their licence authorised them to import. The Customs authorities, on the companytrary. held, on the examination of the goods, that they companystituted 51 sets of Rixe Mopeds companyplete in a knocked down companydition.

facts.text: Customs authorities held that the goods constituted 51 sets of Rixe Mopeds complete in a knocked down condition.

anchor.surface_text: The Customs authorities, on the companytrary. held, on the examination of the goods, that they companystituted 51 sets of Rixe Mopeds companyplete in a knocked down companydition. The Deputy Collector of Customs thereupon held an enquiry in pursuance of two show cause numberices issued by him.

facts.text: Deputy Collector of Customs held an enquiry pursuant to two show cause notices.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Collector of Customs thereupon held an enquiry in pursuance of two show cause numberices issued by him. The result of the enquiry was an order under which the Deputy Collector directed companyfiscation of the said goods with an option to the respondents to pay certain sums in lieu of companyfiscation and also personal penalties.

facts.text: Deputy Collector order dated November 19, 1957 directed confiscation of the goods with option to pay sums in lieu and personal penalties.

anchor.surface_text: That order was passed on the basis that the goods imported were number parts and accessories of motor cycles and scooters permissible under entry 295 of the Schedule to the Import Control Order, but were motor cycles scooters in companypletely knocked down companydition, prohibited under remark II against entry 294, a licence in respect of goods companyered by it would authorise import of motor cycles and Scooters. The order of the Deputy Collector dated November 19, 1957 reads as under

facts.text: On examination, ascertained that M/s. Tarachand Gupta Bros. had imported 51 sets of Rixe Mopeds complete except tyres, tubes and saddles in knocked down condition.

anchor.surface_text: On examination of the goods and scrutiny of the documents relating to the Bills of Entry stated above, it was ascertained that M s. Tarachand Gupta Bros. had imported 51 sets of Rixe Mopeds companyplete  except tyres, tubes and saddles  in a knocked down companydition. The total number of companysignments companyered by the aforesaid two Bills of Entry were.

facts.text: Total consignments covered by two Bills of Entry sufficient to give exactly 51 sets complete Rixe Mopeds except tyres, tubes and saddles.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of companysignments companyered by the aforesaid two Bills of Entry were. sufficient to give exactly 51 sets companyplete, Rixe Mopeds  except for tyres, tubes and saddles which would in any case have required a separate licence . The packing was also such as to show that those were numberhing but Mopeds in a disassembled companydition,

facts.text: Packing showed goods were Mopeds in disassembled condition, each case contains components relating to three mopeds.

anchor.surface_text: The packing was also such as to show that those were numberhing but Mopeds in a disassembled companydition, since each of the cases companytains companyponents relating to three mopeds. Moreover, it was found that major companyponents such as the frames, companypletely fitted with electrical wires and companytrol cables and grips had been imported in equal numbers.

facts.text: Major components like frames completely fitted with electrical wires, control cables and grips imported in equal numbers.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, it was found that major companyponents such as the frames, companypletely fitted with electrical wires and companytrol cables and grips had been imported in equal numbers.-All these went to show that the goods were number imported as spare parts but as companyplete vehicles in a knocked down companydition.

facts.text: Goods considered incorrectly classifiable under item 75(2) of I.C.T. corresponding to S. No. 294, IV of I.T.O. Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: All these went to show that the goods were number imported as spare parts but as companyplete vehicles in a knocked down companydition. The goods were therefore, companysidered to be companyrectly classifiable under item 75 2  of the I.C.T. companyresponding to S. No. 294, IV of the I.T.O. Schedule. The licence under which clearance was sought, companyld number, therefore, be accepted.

facts.text: Deputy Collector rejected contention that two consignments arriving by different ships at different dates should be viewed separately.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Collector rejected the respondents companytention that the two companysignments which arrived in two different ships at different dates should be viewed separately, that the machines were incomplete as they were without tyres, tubes and saddles and therefore they companyld number be said to companystitute motor cycles in knocked down companydition.

facts.text: Deputy Collector held that absence of tyres, tubes, saddles made no difference as they were obtainable in India and trade practice supplied without them.

anchor.surface_text: He held, on the other hand, that though the goods were number in companypletely knocked down companydition it made numberdifference as the tyres, tubes and saddles were easily obtainable in India and their absence did number prevent the machines being otherwise companyplete. He also found that there was a trade practice under which traders were supplying motor cycles without tyres, tubes and saddles unless the purchaser specially asked for these parts.

facts.text: Respondents filed suit in High Court against the Deputy Collector's order.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, the goods companyld number be regarded as spare parts but were Mopeds in disassembled companydition. In the suit filed by the respondents in the High Court against the said-order,

facts.text: Trial Judge held suit time-barred under Art. 14 Limitation Act 1908 and dismissed it, no civil court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On that basis he held the respondents suit to be time barred and dismissed it. We may, at this stage,, mention that in a similar matter involving import of spare parts and accessories under a licence relating to entry 295,

facts.text: In D.P. Anand v. M/s. M. Thakore Co., Division Bench of Bombay High Court held Collector's order bad.

anchor.surface_text: the Collectors order, on the basis that the goods fell under entry 294, as the spare parts in question companyld, it all the different indents were taken together, companystituted auto cycles in companypletely knocked down companydition, was held to be bad as the Collectors approach to the matter was wholly wrong by a Division Bench of the same High Court in D. P. Anand v. M s. M. Thakore Co.

facts.text: Letters Patent Bench of High Court agreed Collector in error, reversed trial judge, held suit within time under Art. 62 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Bench of the High Court, following the judgment in Anands case, 1  agreed with the Trial Judge that on merits the Collector was in error. Following that judgment, the Bench also, held that the Collectors jurisdiction was limited to ascertain whether or number the goods imported by the respondents were spare parts and accessories companyered by entry 295

facts.text: High Court held Collector could not lump two consignments together to conclude 51 Rixe Mopeds in CKD condition.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore, he companyld number have lumped together the two companysignments which, though imported under one licence, arrived separately and were received on different dates and companyld number have companye to the companyclusion that the plaintiffs  i.e. the respondents herein  had imported 51 Rixe mopeds in a companypletely knocked down companydition.

facts.text: Goods did not contain tyres, tubes and saddles.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that, the. goods in question did number admittedly companytain tyres, tubes and saddles, so that it was impossible to say that they companystituted motor cycles and scooters in C.K.D. companydition.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Collector's order in non-compliance with statute, nullity, civil court jurisdiction not excluded.

arguments.claim: Goods imported constituted 51 sets of Rixe Mopeds complete in knocked down condition, not parts and accessories under entry 295 but classifiable under item 75(2) I.C.T. / entry 294 prohibited by remark II

anchor.surface_text: The Customs authorities, on the contrary. held, on the examination of the goods, that they constituted 51 sets of Rixe Mopeds complete in a knocked down condition. The Deputy Collector of Customs thereupon held an enquiry in pursuance of two show cause notices issued by him. The result of the enquiry was an order under which the Deputy Collector directed confiscation of the said goods with an option to the respondents to pay certain sums in lieu of confiscation and also personal penalties. That order was passed on the basis that the goods imported were not parts and accessories of motor cycles and scooters permissible under entry 295 of the Schedule to the Import Control Order, but were motor cycles scooters in completely knocked down condition, prohibited under remark II against entry 294, a licence in respect of goods covered by it would authorise import of motor cycles and Scooters.

arguments.court_reasoning: Collector's jurisdiction limited to checking conformity to entry 295; lumping consignments and applying entry 294 remark exceeds jurisdiction and non-compliant with statute

arguments.claim: Two consignments arriving by different ships at different dates should be viewed separately, not lumped together

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Collector rejected the respondents contention that the two consignments which arrived in two different ships at different dates should be viewed separately, that the machines were incomplete as they were without tyres, tubes and saddles and therefore they could not be said to constitute motor cycles in knocked down condition.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r, a civil companyrt had numberjurisdiction to grant relief. He also held that the order companyld number be said to be without or in excess of jurisd

arguments.court_reasoning: Collector could not lump separate consignments arriving on different dates

arguments.claim: Machines incomplete without tyres, tubes, saddles, so not CKD motor cycles

anchor.surface_text: He held, on the other hand, that though the goods were not in completely knocked down condition it made no difference as the tyres, tubes and saddles were easily obtainable in India and their absence did not prevent the machines being otherwise complete. He also found that there was a trade practice under which traders were supplying motor cycles without tyres, tubes and saddles unless the purchaser specially asked for these parts.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: under one licence, arrived separately and were received on different dates and companyld number have companye to the companyclusion that the plaintif

arguments.court_reasoning: Irrelevant to classification under entry 295; tyres/tubes expressly excluded from 295

arguments.claim: Civil suit does not lie against Collector's final order as within jurisdiction though erroneous; must set aside under Art.14 Limitation Act, suit time-barred

anchor.surface_text: In the suit filed by the respondents in the High Court against the said-order, the Trial Judge held, on the authority of the Secretary of State v. Mask Co. that an order of a statutory tribunal, such as the Collector of Customs under the Sea Customs Act, which the statute makes final, subject, of course, to an appeal provided under it, can be set aside in a suit before a civil court on two grounds only, namely, where the provisions of the Act have not been complied with, or where the tribunal has failed to act in conformity with the fundamental rules of judicial procedure.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Even where a statute gives finality, such a provision does number exclude cases where the provisions of the particular statute have number been compa

arguments.court_reasoning: Order non-compliant with statute, nullity; jurisdiction not excluded per Mask exceptions

arguments.claim: Collector erred on merits by holding goods not covered by licence; bound by Anand precedent

anchor.surface_text: We may, at this stage,, mention that in a similar matter involving import of spare parts and accessories under a licence relating to entry 295, the Collectors order, on the basis that the goods fell under entry 294, as the spare parts in question could, it all the different indents were taken together, constituted auto cycles in completely knocked down condition, was held to be bad as the Collectors approach to the matter was wholly wrong by a Division Bench of the same High Court in D. P. Anand v. M s. M. Thakore Co.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the case fell within the first ground and held that however erroneous the Collectors decision might be since it was within his jurisdiction to decide

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees Collector in error following Anand

arguments.claim: High Court writ jurisdiction differs from civil suit; no suit as order within jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: the Collectors order... was held to be bad... by a Division Bench... in D. P. Anand v. M s. M. Thakore Co. According to that judgment, the jurisdiction of the Collector was to ascertain whether the goods, such as they were, were properly imported under the licence relating to goods under entry 295... The Trial Judge held, on the authority of this judgment that on merits the Collector of Customs was in error... He, however, was of the view that whereas the High Court in D. P. Anands case interfered with the order in its writ jurisdiction. a suit could not lie as the impugned order was within the jurisdiction of the Collector...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: apply because the Governments determination companyld number be said to be one under S. 3  2 . The words a decision or order passed by an officer of

arguments.court_reasoning: Order nullity due to jurisdictional error, suit maintainable

arguments.claim: Collector's jurisdiction limited to whether goods spare parts/accessories under entry 295; cannot lump consignments or check if CKD under 294

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Bench of the High Court, following the judgment in Anands case, agreed with the Trial Judge that on merits the Collector was in error. Following that judgment, the Bench also, held that the Collectors jurisdiction was limited to ascertain whether or not the goods imported by the respondents were spare parts and accessories covered by entry 295... and therefore, he could not have lumped together the two consignments which, though imported under one licence, arrived separately...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: under one licence, arrived separately and were received on different dates and companyld number have companye to the companyclusion that the plaintif

arguments.court_reasoning: Endorses; Collector must only check entry 295 conformity

arguments.claim: Goods entitled under 295, no breach of s.167(8) Sea Customs or s.3 Imports Act; Girdharilal distinguishes Anand but does not overrule

anchor.surface_text: ...and therefore, he could not have come to the conclusion that the plaintiffs i.e. the respondents herein had imported 51 Rixe mopeds in a completely knocked down condition. The, Bench also held that upon the principle laid down in Anands case it was not for the Collector to ascertain whether the goods, if assembled together, would constitute 51 Rixe Mopeds in C.K.D. condition The respondents were entitled to import the said goods, and therefore, s. 167 8 of the Sea Customs Act did not apply... The Bench also held that the decision of this Court in Girdharilal Bansidhar v. Union of India did not overrule but only distinguished the judgment in Anands case, and therefore, the binding force of that decision remained unshaken.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: case was justified in following it. It is true, however, that companynsel for the appellant there relied on that decision in support of his propositi

arguments.claim: Where tribunal decides between entries erroneously but within jurisdiction, no civil suit; but if extraneous considerations or exceeds to entry 295 check, then non-compliance

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the jurisdiction of civil courts, the Division Bench held that where the question is simply whether one or the other entry applies and the tribunal... decides it erroneously... cannot be... subject matter of a suit. On the other hand, where its jurisdiction is confined to see whether the importation is under a particular entry or not, but while deciding such a question, the tribunal ,takes into account extraneous considerations, such as an entry which has no bearing upon the question, the case would fall outside...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: apply because the Governments determination companyld number be said to be one under S. 3  2 . The words a decision or order passed by an officer of

arguments.court_reasoning: Endorses; applies to Collector considering 294 for 295 licence

arguments.claim: Order nullity ab initio as excess jurisdiction, suit under Art.62 Limitation not Art.14

anchor.surface_text: ...The Division Bench deprecated the attempt... Such an attempt... was a new classification conjured up... Lastly, the Division Bench disagreed with the Trial Judge who had held that the article in the Limitation Act applicable was Art. 14, on the ground that once it was accepted that the order was in excess of jurisdiction it was a nullity... Following A. Venkata Subba Rao v. Andhra Pradesh, it held that the suit fell under Art. 62, and therefore, was within time.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Even where a statute gives finality, such a provision does number exclude cases where the provisions of the particular statute have number been compa

arguments.claim: Sea Customs Act vests Collector authority to decide if goods fell within entry 295; final unless non-compliance with Act or NJ violation; here misuse licence for CKD indirectly, within jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Union of India challenged the correctness of ,the judgment of the Division Bench and urged that the Sea Customs Act had clearly vested in the Collector the authority to decide whether the goods in question fell within entry 295 or not and for which the respondents had been granted the licence. His decision... being final, could not be challenged in a suit save under the well recognized exceptions... The present case... was one of importing Rixe Mopeds in C.K.D. condition, not permissible... and therefore, the Trial Judge was right...

arguments.court_reasoning: Collector exceeded by applying 294 to 295 licence; non-compliance/nullity

arguments.claim: Entry 295 permits all parts/accessories of motor cycles/scooters without CKD restriction; no import of remark II from 294

anchor.surface_text: The Imports Control Order 1955... by cl. 3 thereof, provides that no person shall import any goods... except under... licence... Entries 294 and 295... Entry 294 deals with import ,of motorcycles and scooters. Remark ii in its column No. 6 lays down that Licences granted under this item will not be valid for the import of motor cycles scooters in a completely knocked down condition... Entry 295 deals with Articles other than rubber tyres and tubes adapted for use as parts and accessories... There are no remarks against entry 295...

arguments.claim: Importer under 295 can import all parts even if assemblable to CKD; no restriction unlike 294; absence tyres/tubes/saddles confirms not CKD
No indirect import prohibition; hypothetical lumping multiple consignments would absurdly limit 295

anchor.surface_text: No Doubt, there was... finding... trade practice... tyres and tubes could be had... argument was that since... restriction in entry 294... importer could not be allowed to do indirectly... But the question is what have the respondents done indirectly... In the absence of any restrictions in entry 295... the mere fact... would not amount to a breach... Were that to be so, the position would be anomalous... Suppose that an importer were to import equal number... from different countries... If the contention... the Collector can treat them together... Such an approach would mean... limitation against importation...

arguments.claim: Restriction CKD only for 294 licensees, not 295; cannot imply 294 remark into 295

anchor.surface_text: Such a condition was advisedly not placed in entry 295 but was put in entry 294 only. The reason was that import of both motor cycles... under entry 294 and... parts... under entry 295. A trader having a licence... 294 could import assembled... but not... C.K.D... unless... manufacturer... Thus the res- triction not to import... C.K.D... was against... 294... and not against... 295. If Dr. Syed Mohamads contention were to be right we would have to import remark ii against entry 294 into entry 295... Further, such a condition... would not fit in... There is, therefore, no question of a licensee under entry 295 doing indirectly...

arguments.claim: Collector's task: check if parts/accessories under 295, not if comprehensive for CKD

anchor.surface_text: The result is that when the Collector examines goods imported under a licence... 295 what he has to ascertain is whether the. goods are parts and accessories, and not whether the goods... are so comprehensive that if put together would constitute... C.K.D... Were he to adopt such an approach, he would be acting contrary to and beyond entry 295... Such an approach would... be in non-compliance of entry 295.

arguments.claim: Girdharilal distinguishable: there prohibited article components vs here permitted parts; High Court not appeal on merits

anchor.surface_text: The question then is whether such a reading... contrary to... Girdharilal Bansidhar... the principle... High Court... does not sit in appeal... In that case... imported nuts and bolts... components of... prohibited... Court held importing components of prohibited... prohibited... Girdharilals case is clearly distinguishable because it is not as if motor cycles... prohibited... The restriction is not against licensees importing... 294 and parts... 295 but against the licensees under entry 294 importing... C.K.D... The question... was not under which... 294 or 295... but whether... covered by entry 295.

arguments.claim: Finality excludes civil jurisdiction only if compliant with statute/NJ; jurisdictional error/non-compliance makes nullity (Mask, Anisminic, etc.)
Collector considered extraneous (294 remark) beyond 295 check, non-compliance/nullity; civil jurisdiction not excluded

holdings.text: A licence under entry 295 permits the import of all parts and accessories of motor cycles and scooters without restriction on quantity or type, even if they could be assembled into complete vehicles in CKD condition, as there is no such prohibition unlike in entry 294.

anchor.surface_text: Under entry 295... there are no limitations as to the number or kind of parts... Prima facie, an importer could import all the parts... it would not be a ground... that the parts... if assembled, would make motor cycles... in C.K.D. condition. There are no remarks against entry 295...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation distinguishes entry 295 (no remarks/restrictions) from 294 (remark II prohibits CKD); purposive reading avoids implying restrictions; policy allows parts import freely.

holdings.text: Separate consignments under one licence arriving by different ships on different dates cannot be lumped together by customs authorities to determine if they constitute CKD vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: No Doubt, there was... finding... trade practice... tyres and tubes could be had... argument was that since... restriction in entry 294... importer could not be allowed to do indirectly... But the question is what have the respondents done indirectly... Were that to be so, the position would be anomalous...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absurd consequences if lumping allowed (multiple shipments/countries); no textual basis in cl.3 Imports Order or entry 295; each consignment assessed independently.

holdings.text: Customs Collector's jurisdiction under Imports Control Order and Sea Customs Act is limited to ascertaining whether imported goods conform to the description in the licence (entry 295 parts/accessories); enquiring if they form CKD vehicles under entry 294 exceeds jurisdiction and is non-compliant with statute.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that when the Collector examines goods imported under a licence in respect of goods covered by entry 295 what he has to ascertain is whether the. goods are parts and accessories, and not whether the goods... are so comprehensive that if put together would constitute... C.K.D... Were he to adopt such an approach, he would be acting contrary to and beyond entry 295...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies cl.3 Imports Order: licence valid if goods match description; considering extraneous entry 294/remark II is irrelevant and jurisdictional error per Mask precedent.

holdings.text: Girdharilal Bansidhar is distinguishable as it concerned components of prohibited articles under competing entries, whereas here goods are expressly permitted parts under specific entry 295 with no competing prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The question then is whether such a reading... contrary to... Girdharilal Bansidhar... In that case... imported nuts and bolts... components of... prohibited... Court held importing components of prohibited... prohibited... Girdharilals case is clearly distinguishable because it is not as if motor cycles... prohibited...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent analogy: no total prohibition on vehicles/parts; restriction only on CKD under 294 licences; question is conformity to 295, not choice between entries.

holdings.text: Collector's order applying entry 294 criteria to entry 295 licence is a nullity for statutory non-compliance and jurisdictional error; civil court jurisdiction not excluded by finality clauses (s.188 Sea Customs Act), suit maintainable without setting aside.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Mask & Co., Anisminic, Illuri: extraneous considerations (294 remark) make purported order void ab initio; exceptions to exclusion doctrine apply.

holdings.text: Where Collector's order is nullity due to non-compliance/jurisdictional error, Limitation Art.14 (set aside) inapplicable; suit for recovery falls under Art.62.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Nullity ab initio needs no formal setting aside (Venkata Subba Rao); direct recovery suit within time under Art.62.

precedents.citation: Secretary of State v. Mask Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: Secretary of State v. Mask Co. 1  that an order of a statutory tribunal, such as the Collector of Customs under the Sea Customs Act, which the statute makes final, subject, of course, to an appeal provided under it, can be set aside in a suit before a civil court on two grounds only, namely, where the provisions of the Act have not been complied with, or where the tribunal has failed to act in conformity with the fundamental rules of judicial procedure.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v. Mask & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: an order of a statutory tribunal made final by statute can be set aside in suit only where provisions of Act not complied with or tribunal failed to follow fundamental rules of judicial procedure

precedents.citation: D. P. Anand v. M s. M. Thakore Co. 2

anchor.surface_text: D. P. Anand v. M s. M. Thakore Co. 2  According to that judgment, the jurisdiction of the Collector was to ascertain whether the goods, such as they were, were properly imported under the licence relating to goods under entry 295, i.e., whether they were spare parts and accessories, and not to go further and find out whether they would, when put together, constitute auto cycles in completely knocked down condition, as envisaged by entry 294

precedents.case_name: D. P. Anand v. M/s. M. Thakore & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Collector's jurisdiction limited to checking if goods match licence description under entry 295 (parts/accessories), not to consider if they constitute complete vehicles in CKD when assembled

precedents.citation: Girdharilal Bansidhar v. Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: Girdharilal Bansidhar v. Union of India 2  did not overrule but only distinguished the judgment in Anands case, 1  and therefore, the binding force of that decision remained unshaken.

precedents.case_name: Girdharilal Bansidhar v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court does not sit in appeal over correctness of customs authorities' classification of goods under competing entries
precedents.cited_holding: importing components of prohibited article is importing the prohibited article itself

precedents.citation: A. Venkata Subba Rao v. Andhra Pradesh,  1

anchor.surface_text: Following A. Venkata Subba Rao v. Andhra Pradesh,  1  it held that the suit fell under Art. 62, and therefore, was within time.

precedents.case_name: A. Venkata Subba Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: suit against nullity falls under Art. 62 Limitation Act, not Art. 14

precedents.citation: Firm Illuri Subbayya Chetty Sons v. Andhra Pradesh,   3

anchor.surface_text: Firm Illuri Subbayya Chetty Sons v. Andhra Pradesh,   3 the suit filed by the appellants was for recovery of a sum paid by way of purchase tax under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939. The cause of action was that the amount had been illegally recovered.

precedents.case_name: Firm Illuri Subbayya Chetty & Sons v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: even incorrect assessment within jurisdiction is not non-compliance with statute if made under the Act

anchor.surface_text: This principle was repeated in Dhulabhai v. Madhya Pradesh 1  where it was held that where a statute gives finality to the orders of the special tribunal the civil courts jurisdiction must be held to be excluded if there is adequate remedy to correct an assessment which is erroneous.

precedents.case_name: Dhulabhai v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: finality to tribunal orders excludes civil court jurisdiction where adequate remedy exists to correct erroneous assessments

anchor.surface_text: The case of Panthulu v. Andhra Pradesh  4  illustrates as to when an authority can be said to have acted in non- compliance with the provisions of the statute under which it derives its authority.

precedents.case_name: Panthulu v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: acting on irrelevant evidence or material not pertaining to the matter is non-compliance with statute and excess of jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Anisminic Ltd. v. The Foreign Compensation Commission 1

anchor.surface_text: In Anisminic Ltd. v. The Foreign Compensation Commission 1  Lord Reid at pages 213 and 214 of the Report stated as follows It has sometimes been said that it is only where a tribunal acts without jurisdiction that its decision is a nullity.

precedents.case_name: Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission
precedents.cited_proposition: tribunal decision is nullity if it misconstrues provisions, takes irrelevant considerations, fails natural justice, etc., even if had jurisdiction to enter inquiry
precedents.cited_holding: quoted extensively on errors making decision nullity

precedents.citation: R, v. Fulham, Hammersmith and Kensington Rent Tribunal 1

anchor.surface_text: R, v. Fulham, Hammersmith and Kensington Rent Tribunal 1  is yet another decision of a tribunal properly embarking on an enquiry, that is, within its jurisdiction, but at the end of it making an order in excess of its jurisdiction which was held to be a nullity

precedents.case_name: R. v. Fulham, Hammersmith & Kensington Rent Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: tribunal order in excess of jurisdiction during inquiry is nullity even if type of order it could make properly

Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
